climbs.name: Right Between the Eyes
climbs.fa: Jan. 3rd. 2021 Tony Becchio, Darren Odgers, and Bob “Trad Bob” Drescher

content.description: Getting to, and past the 3rd bolt is the crux. After passing the 4th bolt at the mini roof is a big ledge. The climbing eases from here. Climb directly up between the two caves/“eyes”, passing 4 more bolts.  After clipping the last bolt, an interesting little slab move will get you to the anchor.
content.location: Far right side of cliff, just up and about 20 ft. off the road. About 12 ft. left of “Elephant in the Room”, and 15 ft. right of “ Mowgli Walk”. Look for the two big caves half way up the wall. The F.A. was done from the drainage gully right next to the road, same start as “Elephant in the Room” except angle up and left to the 1st. bolt. This makes the route about 100ft.

climbs.name: Teenage Mastodon
climbs.fa: F. T. R.  Jeremy Palaszewski.  Sept.  2021

content.description: From the holds at the lip in the center of the roof, reach the small, but positive rail. Then bring your feet up to the lip of the roof. Climbing eases from here. Finish on the last half of “Orphaned Elephant”
content.location: Center of the roof between “Orphaned Elephant” and “Baby Mammoth”

climbs.name: Orphaned Elephant
climbs.fa: Unknown 1980’s. Retro-bolted: Tony Becchio & Niko Georghiou Sept. 2021

content.description: From the chossy and (Ugh) dirty ledge climb the 2ft roof to the fist sized hueco/hole. Once standing in the hole move right, then straight up passing two more bolts on edges and holes then angle right to the anchor
content.location: Start just right of “Elephant in the Room”  follow the right angling line of bolts passing the tiny cave/flake feature on the left. Shares anchor with “Baby Mammoth”

content.description: Layback and stem for 15 feet up a dihedral.  Exit the dihedral, escaping left and then up onto a ledge above.  Move left and then climb an easy ramp up to a steep headwall.  Thin edging leads up vertical rock past the crux.
content.location: The route starts in a 15-foot tall, right-facing dihedral that is located 40 feet left and 20 feet up from the start of Elephant in the Room.

content.description:
Things are not as they seem...the steepest part of this route is surprisingly easy.  The slabby upper reaches are surprisingly hard.  All in all a fun addition to Derrydale.

The route follows steep face climbing on positive edges past the first two bolts--amazingly, solid edges appear wherever they are needed.  Just below the third bolt, the angle drops back.  From here, delicate slab climbing leads past two more bolts.  There is a clear crux encounter just above the fourth bolt.  If you escape right, it is possible to bypass the hardest moves.  Finish to the left on the anchors of Mammoth Poaching.
content.location: The route begins about 15 feet to the right of the start of Mammoth Poaching.

content.description:
Exilis Dihedral climbs the most striking feature on the cliff--a large, left-facing dihedral in the center of the formation.

Delicate slab climbing past three bolts (crux) leads to the dihedral.  Laybacking and stemming deposits you at the top of the dihedral on a large ledge.  A few easy fifth-class moves take you over the final bulge to a rap anchor on a spacious ledge.
content.protection: Four bolts (all 1/2" sleeve bolts), gear from a #0 TCU up to 2-1/2"
content.location: The dihedral is located almost in the dead-center of the wall.  Scramble up the loose hillside directly below the dihedral to access the start.

content.description:
Varied climbing through three tiers of rock on the tallest part of the wall.

The route starts with steep face climbing on positive holds (5.8+) on rock that is strangely reminiscent of San Ysidro.  Upon reaching a ledge atop the first tier, the route follows blocks up and slightly right, in the direction of an obvious overhang.  The route then follows positive holds up to the roof.  A devilish mantel leads to easy slab-climbing.

The route ends on a wide, grassy ledge in what feels like a rocky amphitheater--the position is excellent.

The route can be rappelled with 2 ropes.
content.protection: 7 bolts (all 1/2" Rawls), yellow TCU, 1-inch cam.  Bolted top anchor with rappel rings.
content.location:
The routes starts in a gully next to the road, on the right hand side of the crag.  Click

here

for location.

climbs.name: Black Tide (A.K.A. Surfing with Elephants)
climbs.fa: Tony Becchio, Darren Odgers, Matt Spencer and Lori Hansen.  Mar. 21st. 2021

content.description: Boulder problem crux start, leads to the sweeping, almost-breaking-wave like headwall
content.protection: 5 bolts, 2 bolt anchor with chains. If you plan on TRing bring a cordelette or several slings to get you over the lip. Bolts are about 3 to 4 ft. back
content.location: 15 ft. right of “Grand Old Pachyderm” and 20 ft. Left of “Mowgli Walk”  start in the body length dihedral of white rock surrounded by black rock.

content.description: Crux moves are right off the chossy ledge. A high left foot gets you going and into the good edges. Go over the small cave/flake feature on the right. Climb past two more bolts on good crimps and holes to the anchor. Shares anchor with “Orphaned Elephant”
content.location: 15 ft. right of “Orphaned Elephant”. Just right of where the small roof ends

climbs.name: Barbecued Mammoth
climbs.fa: Dec. 6th 2020  Tony Becchio and Darren Odgers

content.description: Face climb up the black streak past the big yellow/green lichen patch on the left, to the 5 1/2 inch wide, but short roof crack to the anchors. Crux between 2nd and 3rd bolt. Another balancy crux after clipping the 4th bolt. The route is still new and has some Choss on it, just like all the other routes on the cliff. But most of the holds are pretty solid
content.protection:
5 bolts, and a #6 Cam, or an older style #5

Bolted anchor with chain links. ( I’ll put Mussy’s on it later,  if it gets popular.  Maybe
content.location: Just about dead center of the entire cliff. Approximately 60-70 ft left of “Exilis Dihedral” and about 40 ft right of the unknown 5.11 and 5.12 routes. Look for the wide but short roof crack at the top. Straight up from the newly resurrected trail that starts just on the right side of the dirt parking area.

content.description:
A varied and interesting route.

Steep and strenuous climbing past the first three bolts (crux) yields to low-angle slabbing.  Near the top of the route, there is a committing, dynamic mantle onto a ledge and then an easy scramble to the anchors.
content.location: 30 feet to the right of Exilis Dihedral
